comments.commentBody: You are right. I was a little taken aback that Romney had already started to send out invitations to the inauguration to his buddies. A little presumptive, I think, but it also makes one think that maybe they know something we don't. (Read: Diebold).

Americans need to bear in mind that it isn't just Flip the Flop whom the President will be running against.  We've already heard mutterings from the Teapublicans in the House to the effect that THEY'LL be running things if Romney is elected.  Their standard-bearer may try to convince voters that he's a moderate but the loons who control the House can't even pretend that they're anything but ruthless reactionaries. Nor do they have any inclination to.  We need a second term for Mr. Obama just to protect the rest of America from the predations of the Tea Party.

Whatever those wounds were, they clearly weren't that bad, as there was no evidence of them a short while later in the police video.  Also, just because he has wounds does not mean that he's not in the wrong...again, the stalker, the aggressor, the shooter vs. a young man walking around minding his own business...I still don't see why everyone is so confused.

Sorry, but you are wrong.  It is not criminal to not follow the statement of a 911 operator.  And simply saying "we don't need you to do that" isn't a directive anyway.  And under the Florida law, punching someone very well can mean the person punched can react with deadly.  Instead of deciding based purely on emotion, try reading the law that applies first and vent your anger at the law.  Zimmerman didn't do anything that the applicable law doesn't contemplate and, in many cases, sanction.

The scariest thing about this incident is the revelation that there are so many people in this country willing to  jump to conclusions before they know the facts, and second-guess the actions of another person who was in a stressful situation, at best. This is a guy who called the police and asked them to come out- not one who wanted to take the law into his hands. This is a guy whose neighborhood was having problems with crime- thus, the neighborhood watch- and volunteered to put himself on the front line to help provide a safe place to live for his neighbors. And yes, this is a guy who had a gun on him. And what does that mean here? It means that, for all we  know, Trayvon may have tried to take his weapon to shoot him with it. Until the facts come out, no one should be passing judgment on Mr. Zimmerman-- especially not the race baiters like Jackson and Sharpton. And the press shouldn't be egging them on. Shame on everyone who has glommed onto this story as an excuse to cry racism.

The paramedics who treated Zimmerman at the scene will testify.  Let's wait for that evidence, shall we?  Even if Zimmerman turns out to be found not guilty, that doesn't mean he shouldn't have been charged.  In theory, one can bring an abuse of prosecutorial discretion claim against the DA there is not a scintilla of evidence against the accused. That won't be the case here, no matter the outcome.

I don't see the relevance of whether he was part of a neighborhood watch.  Florida has liberal gun ownership laws, Zimmerman owned a gun--lawfully I presume since I haven't heard otherwise--and he found something suspicious about Martin and looked into it.  Lots of people would do the same thing, most without a gun.  Zimmerman's suspicions may or may have been reasonable the point isn't that he was or wasn't in a neighborhood watch; the point is just about anyone can have a gun for the asking.

The only comments the President made, i.e., "if I had a son he'd look like Trayvon," were in response to a reporter's question at a press conference...a question the President was wise enough to know would be coming.  To not answer or to shy away would be more in keeping with his opponent in the upcoming election.  So when exactly did he make this "speech" you refer to, and what did he say?

The problem with your description is Trayvon would not be entitled under the Florida law to "jump" Zimmerman because he felt "uncomfortable" or felt "anxiety".  If those were Trayvon's feelings, his actions do not fall within the protection of the stand your ground defense.  He had to have REASONABLY felt a threat of serious bodily harm or death.  Being uncomfortable or anxious is insufficient to invoke the stand your ground law.  If it happened as you describe, Zimmerman should be found not guilty.

Oh, and by the way, this story was initially not known outside of Florida until several weeks after it happened.  It was largely the work of a savvy attorney (Benjamin Crump) who wanted people to know.
I'd say the law is on Zimmerman's side in this case, although it will be close.  I'm not remotely surprised he was given bail.

It is just so odd that he would say this. One of the few things we know for 100 percent certain in that Zimmeran told the 911 dispatcher that he thought Trayvon was "in his late teens." Which was correct. Why would he now claim he didn't know that. It makes him seem like a pathogoical liar.
His father did NOT live there silly. His father's girlfriend lived there.
Nope.  The fact that he approached Trayvon despite the 911 recipients request not to do so negates that.

Come on, Phil.  He's on trial for murder, he's not going to say he is sorry for his actions.  If I had heard him say that, I would think his lawyers should be removed from the case for ineffective assistance of counsel.

Negative, the most successful demographic group are recent African immigrants. They have the highest PhD rate and highest average income. The same is true of their children. Many raise their children in violent inner city neighborhoods, yet they succeed too. A similar story pops up with Afro Caribbean immigrants.

Yes, much of a child's education foundation already is set by the time they reach Kindergarten. Much of a child's educational success is due to parental vigilance and encouragement.

Martin Weiss: Where do you get this stuff? Neither this, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Lakes, nor this, http://www.great-lakes.net/humanhealth/lake/michigan.html says anything about BP polluting Lake Michigan. great-lakes.net does note that "the drinking water in the Lake Michigan basin is of good quality."

And you think tornadoes have more than doubled? Since when? Yesterday? Last year? After the 2011 outbreaks it was widely reported--including on this very blog--that there has been *no* increasing trend in the number or intensity of tornadoes over many decades.

In previous comments on this blog you have claimed, without any evidence, that "hundreds of thousands of tons" of nuclear waste have been dumped in the oceans. That would be an enormous amount; it seems you should be able to easily back up a figure like that.

You are right about the passenger pigeons, but not much else. What do you think you're accomplishing by writing such nonsense?

Passenger pigeons once darkened the skies from horizon to horizon for hours. You don't know what you've got 'till it's gone. Pave paradise and put up a parking lot. Dig the well before you get thirsty. There were once so many birds Audubon shot hundreds of them every day without making a noticeable dent. Now we see oysters dying from upwelling warm water, corals bleaching out of life, thirty thousand Europeans dying in heat waves, three thousand coyotes converging on Atlanta. And still people assert we can kill top predators and BP pollutes the drinking water of twenty million people in Lake Michigan and poisons the birthing grounds of millions in the Gulf. Tornadoes have more than doubled and extreme weather events are rife. "A hard rains a'gonna fall."
"The best lack conviction and the worst are full of passionate intensity."-- Yeats
And twice each day, the lemmings sit in gridlock, ignoring the precipice ahead. When food and water can't be had for love or money, it'll be too late to have the luxury of hindsight on the vanished immensities of passenger pigeons. Humanity, itself, even at seven billion, is now an endangered species.

Profiling is irrelevant. Following someone is not illegal.
If he punched George in the nose and was beating his head on the ground, covered his mouth and nose and tried to disarm him, the only response is to regain control of the weapon and fire it into the other person until they are no longer a threat to you. That was his only choice. That was Martins choice.

Maybe someone needs to bang your head on the concrete to make you understand how dangerous that is, and that contrary to your assertion, such injury can be deadly. The skull is fragile and can easily be broken by a rock, a bullet, a sharp object. Then the brain goes out and the person dies.

Given what facts have come to the light so far, I do not know who was the attacker in the case of Martin and Zimmerman, and who had the right to stand his ground. However, I do know you are completely wrong about how dangerous such injuries to the head are. Go to a local trauma center and you will see how often people die after much smaller injuries to their head.
If you never see mentioned Martin's right to "stand his ground" you haven't been reading much.  That's the mantra of all the people who have already found Zimmerman guilty.

Zimmerman and his whole family have received death threats.  THAT is what validates the notion that at least some of Zimmerman's "detractors" certainly do seem violent.  I think it eminently reasonable that Zimmerman's family would testify by phone.

Wow Tom, you are either trolling or have no concept on what self defense or stand your ground means. Going back to his car to get something even a gun is in no way shape or form a justifiable reason to attack someone in self defense or covered in stand your ground. Not even close buddy.
What if when George went back to his truck Martin left? Ran to his dad's girlfriends house?
FYI, guns don't just go off. Especially not double action only kel Tec pf9's.

I wish people would stop talking about Skittles!  Nobody could have known he had Skittles.  This is just spin to make it sounds like Traynor was some six-year-old girl skipping through the neighborhood.

Gene:  Nothing in Jon W's post reflects a desire to see Martin deemed guilty of something.  I've been reading the NYT stories on this for some time and, I'd say Jon W is a lawyer, like me, and one of the only commenters who understands what the statute actually says and is simply applying that law "facts" as we currently know them, rather than basing his judgments purely on emotion.  In fact, I'd bet that Jon W feels much as I do:  that the statute is morally wrong and should be repealed but that, under the statute as it stands, Zimmerman may well be not guilty.

MO is correct that following someone is not a crime. I have also commented that if he feared for his life he should have called the police.  But even if you are correct that, as a black person he wouldn't have felt comfortable doing that (a proposition I find highly dubious), why not call his father or even a neighbor?  But the fact remains, that if he "reasonably" feared for his life, he was entitled to use deadly force.  But it will be pretty hard to prove that he feared for his life just by being followed, but it is possible.

Just FYI, since this is an often misstated piece of information, Zimmerman was calling on a non-emergency line, i.e., not 9-1-1, and his decision to ignore the instruction was not illegal.  Not saying that what he did was right, just tired of having this fact misstated.
